Kiara is a fictional character in Disney's The Lion King franchise. Introduced in ''The Lion King II: Simba's Pride (1998) and appears in The Lion Guard (2015–2019) and Mufasa: The Lion King (2024).'' She is the daughter of  Simba, and Nala, future queen of the Pride Lands. Voiced by Michelle Horn as a cub and Neve Campbell as a young adult. Her singing voices were provided by Liz Callaway and Charity Sanoy.
Kiara is introduced in the ending of The Lion King (1994) as the child of Simba and Nala. The story begins with Kiara, a playful and adventurous lioness wanting to explore the Pride Lands. Simba with his past experiences is overprotective and repeatably request, that Timon and Pumbaa watch after her. In a turn of events Kiara runs off to the Outlands where she befriends Kovu whilst escaping from crocodiles. Shortly after they are separated by their respective parents. Kiara is later rescued as a young adult by Kovu as a part of Zira's vengeance to murder Simba the King of the Pride Lands to avenge the death of Scar. This leads to the two of them falling in love and Kovu attempting to become a member of the Pride Lands. Later when Kovu is exiled Kiara goes to find him to reunite the the Outsiders with the Pride Landers. Alongside Kovu, Kiara goes to end the fight between Zira and Simba, and their lioness'. Kiara eventually breaks up the fighting. Kiara attempts to help Zira forgive the past and move on but does not succeed, in the end Zira meets her fate as she for the last time refuses the help of Kiara.
In The Lion Guard
In The Lion Guard (2015–2019) which takes place during Kiara's "teen years", Kiara is an older cub who takes more part in the oversight of the Pride Lands and maintains a good relationship with her brother, Kion who is the leader of the Lion Guard. Kiara and Kion work together and can also be seen playing together as well. When her father is not around Kiara takes care of the Pride Lands and is responsible for maintaining the Circle of Life.
Alongside Kion, Kiara maintains friendship with Tiifu and Zuri who are her friends. Unlike them Kiara is more mature and demonstrates early signs of leadership and responsibility, and her ability to be the next queen of the Pride Lands. The three lionesses' often end up finding themselves in need of the Lion Guard as Tiifu and Zuri cause trouble and chaos.
The last episode of the show "Return to the Pride Lands" she and Kovu have become partners. This is where the story realigns and takes place after The Lion King II: Simba's Pride. She tells Kion what has happened in the Pride Lands whilst he and the Lion Guard were away at the Tree of Life. Kiara asks Kion to return to the Pride Lands after learning that he had fallen in love with Rani the young queen of the Tree of Life. Kiara is later there to see Kion become Rani's partner and the King of the Tree of Life.
In Mufasa: The Lion King
Kiara makes an appearance in Mufasa: The Lion King (2024), the prequal to the The Lion King (2019 film). At the start of the movie Simba and Nala leave Kiara in the care of Timon and Pumbaa, and are not seen until the end. In the movie Kiara is portrayed as a young cub who listens to Rafiki tell the story of the first king of the Pride Lands: Mufasa. At the end of the film Kiara gets to meet her newborn brother, Kion.
Reception
Critical Reception
Some critics felt Kiara’s early character in The Lion King II was compelling and likable, though later commentary suggested her presence in Mufasa: The Lion King was diminished.”:
“This character was fierce and exciting in The Lion King II, to the point that she was even more likable than Simba had been… but Kiara’s role in Mufasa was under-utilised.”
Public Reception
Among public and fan commentary, Kiara has found favourable reception as a character who brings a fresh dynamic to the franchise. Reviewers highlighted her adventurous nature and self-discovery arc, with one noting she ‘wasn’t good at everything just because of who she was’. Others described her as ‘independent, free-spirited, confident and curious’, marking a link to her father’s youthful spirit. On the other hand, some fans criticize her for lacking uniqueness and recurring traits of previous characters in the franchise.
